importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the occurrence of Diwali celebrations and the resulting spike in air pollution in New Delhi, with the air quality index reaching 442.
The start date of Diwali festivities, during which fireworks began being set off, contributing to the pollution crisis in New Delhi.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Diwali festival period (October 18–23) is when fireworks are traditionally set off, leading to a significant and recurring spike in air pollution in New Delhi.

keyTakeAways: New Delhi’s air quality reached a hazardous level of 442 on Tuesday, making it one of the most polluted cities globally due to Diwali fireworks and seasonal pollution sources.
PM2.5 levels in New Delhi were over 59 times higher than the World Health Organization’s recommended annual limit.
India’s Supreme Court allowed the use of 'green crackers' for up to three hours on Sunday and Monday, but widespread violations occurred.
The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) classified the air quality as 'very poor' with an AQI of 350.
Air quality in Lahore, Pakistan, was also severely affected, with an AQI of 234, indicating widespread regional pollution due to cross-border emissions from Indian Punjab and agricultural fires.
The Ministry of Earth Sciences forecast that air quality in Delhi and surrounding areas will remain 'Very Poor to Poor' for several days.
Historically, Delhi has faced deadly smog events, such as in November 2024 when the AQI reached over 1,700.
Punjab’s Environment Protection Agency identified pollution from Indian Punjab as a major factor affecting air quality in Pakistani Punjab.

namedEntities.name: Diwali
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Hindu festival of lights celebrated annually from October 18–23, during which fireworks are traditionally set off.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The festival triggers a surge in air pollution due to widespread fireworks, making it a central cause of the hazardous air quality in New Delhi.

namedEntities.name: New Delhi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The capital city of India, known for severe winter smog and poor air quality.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the location where the most hazardous air quality readings were recorded, highlighting the severity of pollution in major urban centers in South Asia.

namedEntities.name: IQAir
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Swiss air quality monitoring firm.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided the global air quality index (AQI) measurement of 442 for New Delhi, placing it among the world’s most polluted cities.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The concentration of PM2.5 in New Delhi was more than 59 times the WHO annual guideline, indicating extreme health risks.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rated New Delhi’s air quality as 'very poor' with an AQI of 350, providing an official assessment of pollution levels.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Intended as a mitigation measure, but widely violated, leading to continued pollution.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Experienced high pollution levels (AQI 234), illustrating cross-border air pollution effects from Indian agricultural and industrial sources.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A major source of pollution affecting both Delhi and neighboring areas in Pakistan through cross-border smog.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Indian government department responsible for monitoring environmental conditions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Projected continued 'Very Poor to Poor' air quality in Delhi for days to come, offering a forecast of pollution persistence.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international health organization that sets global health standards.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Set the recommended annual PM2.5 guideline, which was exceeded by over 59 times in New Delhi.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the Diwali festival in October 2025, fireworks set off in New Delhi significantly worsened air quality, with the city’s AQI reaching 442 — the highest recorded globally — due to elevated PM2.5 levels over 59 times the WHO’s annual guideline. While India’s Supreme Court allowed limited use of eco-friendly 'green crackers' for three hours on Sunday and Monday, widespread violations led to continued pollution. The Central Pollution Control Board rated the air as 'very poor' at 350. The Ministry of Earth Sciences forecasts that poor air quality will persist through the week. Regional pollution is exacerbated by agricultural fires in Indian Punjab, which contribute to smog affecting neighboring Lahore, Pakistan, where air quality also reached a high of 234. This event underscores the growing regional environmental crisis in South Asia, where seasonal and cultural activities intensify air pollution and impact public health across borders.
title: Diwali provokes ‘hazardous’ alert over New Delhi air quality
